texts.shortText:
Myzostomids are a very unusual group of polychaetes with superficially unsegmented, oval bodies that lack any distinct head and have only five pairs of short, hooked, caterpillar-like appendages. All are obligatory symbionts of echinoderms, particularly crinoids, and while most are mobile and roam over the host, stealing food from it, others form galls or cysts around themselves, or are internal parasites living in the gut, body cavity or gonads.

This is a free-roaming, oval species found only on the arms of the elegant feather-star Tropiometra carinata. It has a yellow ground colour and a row of five oval black patches dorsally along each side, the overall effect closely matching the colour pattern of its host. It is the only free-living myzostomid currently known from South Africa, and the only species found in the temperate waters of the Atlantic coast. Other species have been seen and photographed on crinoids along the tropical east coast though and these may well represent other, undescribed species.

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Currently known only from False Bay.

This species was only recently discovered and is currently reported only from False Bay, although as its host has an extensive distribution from False Bay eastwards, its true range is almost certainly much more extensive. Individuals are seen moving along the arms of the host and are thought to steal food from the ambulacral groove by reaching around with the proboscis and sucking this up!

In False Bay 62% of hosts inspected carried at least one myzostomid and infected individuals carried a mean of 7 and a maximun of 32 myzostomids each.
Parasitic, stealing food from the ambulacral groove running down the arms of the host.

Mysostomids are hermaphrodite, some changing from initially being male to female as they grow and others (including this species) being simultaneous hermaphrodites. Males have paired penises and fertilization is internal. The fertilized eggs of other Myzostoma species are very small (50 microns in diameter) and are released into the water, where they give rise to non-feeding planktonic larvae, which have a short larval life of 5-8 days before settling on new hosts. After settling, the larvae undergo further development in a cyst before becoming free-living.
Unmistakable and the only free-living myzostomid currently known from the temperate regions of South Africa.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 64).

Lanterbecq, D, Hempson, T, Griffiths, C & Eeckhaut, I (2009). Myzostoma fuscomaculatum (Myzostomida), a new myzostome species from False Bay, South Africa. Hydrobiologia 619, 145-154.
